articles.headline: No Ikea Shelves, No Levis: The Retail Exodus From Russia Is On
articles.snippet: Since the invasion of Ukraine began, the increasing financial and reputational risks of doing business in Russia are leading Western brands to halt operations.
articles.abstract: Since the invasion of Ukraine began, the increasing financial and reputational risks of doing business in Russia are leading Western brands to halt operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Monday, the chief financial officer of Stanley Black & Decker told investors that the company was still figuring out whether it was going to keep its business in Russia given new sanctions affecting the country, or exit in coming weeks or months.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: How a Playground for the Rich Could Undermine Sanctions on Oligarchs
articles.snippet: Allies of President Vladimir Putin, arriving on private jets and yachts, are still welcome in the U.A.E., which has yet to condemn the Ukraine invasion or enforce sanctions.
articles.abstract: Allies of President Vladimir Putin, arriving on private jets and yachts, are still welcome in the U.A.E., which has yet to condemn the Ukraine invasion or enforce sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stretching into the Persian Gulf from the beaches and skyscrapers of Dubai is a man-made archipelago in the shape of a vast palm tree, its branchlike rows of islands lined with luxury hotels, apartments and villas.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Mona El-Naggar and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: After a Week of Siege, Bloodied Mariupol Plans Mass Graves
articles.snippet: Under a relentless Russian barrage, there is no heat or electricity, and people are boiling snow for water. A 6-year-old died of dehydration, the authorities said.
articles.abstract: Under a relentless Russian barrage, there is no heat or electricity, and people are boiling snow for water. A 6-year-old died of dehydration, the authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Marina Levinchuk said she received an alarming text message from the local authorities in the besieged city of Mariupol several days ago, before she decided to flee. “If somebody dies in your family,” she said, recalling the message in her own words, “just put the body outside, cover it, tie up the hands and the legs and leave it outside.”

articles.headline: They Died by a Bridge in Ukraine. This Is Their Story.
articles.snippet: Tetiana Perebyinis and her two children were killed trying to dash to safety, a moment captured by our photographer. Her husband describes their lives, and their final hours.
articles.abstract: Tetiana Perebyinis and her two children were killed trying to dash to safety, a moment captured by our photographer. Her husband describes their lives, and their final hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — They met in high school but became a couple years later, after meeting again on a dance floor at a Ukrainian nightclub. Married in 2001, they lived in a bedroom community outside Kyiv, in an apartment with their two children and their dogs, Benz and Cake. She was an accountant and he was a computer programmer.

articles.headline: Russia Bombards Ukraine Cities and Accuses U.S. of ‘Economic War’
articles.snippet: Misery deepened in Ukraine, where millions of people were caught in besieged cities, and in Russia, where the West’s economic sanctions were biting hard.
articles.abstract: Misery deepened in Ukraine, where millions of people were caught in besieged cities, and in Russia, where the West’s economic sanctions were biting hard.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian forces bombarded Ukrainian cities, prevented hundreds of thousands of civilians from escaping and destroyed a maternity hospital on Wednesday, while the Kremlin accused the United States of waging “an economic war” against Russia.

articles.headline: House Passes $1.5 Trillion Spending Bill as Democrats Drop Covid Aid
articles.snippet: Facing disputes over how to cover the cost of the pandemic response effort, Democrats dropped it rather than jeopardize legislation that includes aid for Ukraine and other top priorities.
articles.abstract: Facing disputes over how to cover the cost of the pandemic response effort, Democrats dropped it rather than jeopardize legislation that includes aid for Ukraine and other top priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday passed a sprawling $1.5 trillion federal spending bill that includes a huge infusion of aid for war-torn Ukraine and money to keep the government funded through September, after jettisoning a package to fund President Biden’s new Covid-19 response effort.

articles.headline: Russia’s War Is Raising Gas Prices and Roiling Financial Markets
articles.snippet: The price of gasoline is climbing and the markets are adjusting to gloomier prospects as the war in Ukraine grinds on.
articles.abstract: The price of gasoline is climbing and the markets are adjusting to gloomier prospects as the war in Ukraine grinds on.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s getting to the point where you’re better off filling up your gas tank in the morning because the price will be higher by the time you drive home.

articles.headline: Surging U.S. Inflation Raises Stakes as War Pushes Up Prices
articles.snippet: Consumer Price Index inflation has been boosted by gas prices but also by increases across a wide variety of products and services.
articles.abstract: Consumer Price Index inflation has been boosted by gas prices but also by increases across a wide variety of products and services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prices climbed at the fastest pace in decades in the month leading up to the war in Ukraine, underlining the high stakes facing the United States — along with many developed economies — as the conflict promises to drive costs higher.

articles.headline: A Two-Year, 50-Million-Person Experiment in Changing How We Work
articles.snippet: The office was never one size fits all. It was one size fits some, with the expectation that everybody else would squeeze in.
articles.abstract: The office was never one size fits all. It was one size fits some, with the expectation that everybody else would squeeze in.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kristen Egziabher was all jitters just before the pandemic, awaiting news of a possible raise, until her manager came back dejected from his meeting with the higher-ups.

articles.headline: A Potential Rarity in American Politics: A Fair Congressional Map
articles.snippet: This year’s congressional map, despite continued gerrymandering, is poised to have a nearly equal number of districts that lean Democratic and Republican.
articles.abstract: This year’s congressional map, despite continued gerrymandering, is poised to have a nearly equal number of districts that lean Democratic and Republican.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, America’s congressional map favored Republicans over Democrats.

articles.headline: Europe prepares for reverberations of war: a slower economy and faster inflation.
articles.snippet: The European Central Bank is moving ahead with plans to end its bond-buying programs amid rising inflation.
articles.abstract: The European Central Bank is moving ahead with plans to end its bond-buying programs amid rising inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as Europe was emerging from a downturn caused by the Omicron variant of the coronavirus, Russia’s war against Ukraine has sent energy prices soaring and shaken forecasts of the region’s economic health.

articles.headline: 4 Falsehoods Russians Are Told About the War
articles.snippet: Russia’s disinformation machine is working in overdrive inside its own borders.
articles.abstract: Russia’s disinformation machine is working in overdrive inside its own borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s international disinformation campaign seemed to flounder in the early days of the invasion, as narratives about Ukrainian bravery dominated the internet. But in Russia, the country’s propaganda machine was busy churning out a deluge of misinformation aimed at its own citizens.

articles.headline: The New Financial Supermarkets
articles.snippet: Private-equity firms were once niche players serving big clients. Now they’re trying to be everything to everyone.
articles.abstract: Private-equity firms were once niche players serving big clients. Now they’re trying to be everything to everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three decades ago, Jonathan Gray might have been an unlikely candidate to become Blackstone’s president and expected successor to its chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman.
